data.title: I18N Support on extensions ?
data.body:
Hi,

I'm working on an extension authoring and I've found a way to define translation keys on package.json (with package.nls.json) but I'm wondering how to do the same with my code and also start some translations (english/french).

I've didn't find anything about this in the documentation but maybe I'm missing something.

Best Regards,
Ioan

data.title: Glob: server/**/**.js should not match server.js

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
Description: 
I'm having problems to define a pattern to exclude files of the view.
Let define that we've this folder directory project:

```
+ Project
    + server
        + folder2
            - file2.ts
            - file2.js 
        - file1.ts
        - file1.js
- server.js
```

I want to exclude ``**.js``files. So, a define the pattern ``server/**/**.js``, but vscode is interpreting that "server/" is a file, and the project folder looks like that, after the pattern.

```
+ Project
    + server
        + folder2
            - file2.ts
        - file1.ts
```

Vscode excludes ``server.js` ` too. There is a gif below showing the behavior:

**Gif below:**

![](http://im2.ezgif.com/tmp/ezgif.com-537ce5f92a.gif)

data.title: Drag for multiple cursors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Manjaro Linux 16.10.3

Could you include a feature similar to what Sublime Text has, where you can hold ALT and drag your mouse with the right button clicked to create multiple cursors on different lines? I really feel like this feature is missing. Thanks a lot!

data.title: Instant markdown preview displays text out of bounds when editor UI is zoomed out
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9 and 1.10 insiders
- OS Version: Arch Linux x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Zoom editor out *(e.g. by pressing Ctrl+-)*
2. Open a markdown file and instant preview on the side
3. Text in the preview will go out of bounds 
4. Zooming the editor back to the default will fix the issue

![screenshot from 2017-02-04 11-36-41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/918661/22618194/88f211cc-eace-11e6-9b72-c2867172c30c.png)

data.title: Add _ to the default value of "editor.wordSeparators"
data.body:
Hi everybody.

It seems that `_` isn't part of default value of **editor.wordSeparators**.
It seems weird to me.
I am opening this issue to collect opinions whether other people also want `_` to be part of **editor.wordSeparators**.

data.title: [decorators] Single quotes in the contentText make the content not being rendered at all
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Before 1.9.0, a code like
```javascript
decoration.renderOptions = {after: {contentText: "'a'" }};
```
rendered `'a'` decoration text. In 1.9.0, nothing is rendered.

data.body:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.5|
|local-history|xyz|1.1.0|

---
This worked perfectly. Upgraded and it is broken. How do downgrade to the last version NOW?
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch.json:
```
{
	"version": "1.9.0",
	"configurations": [				
		{			 
			"name": "Launch",
			"type": "node",
			"request": "launch",
			"program": "${workspaceRoot}/startup.js",
			"stopOnEntry": false,
			"args": [],
			"cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
			"runtimeExecutable": null,
			"runtimeArgs": [
				"--nolazy"
			],
			"env": {
				"NODE_ENV": "development",
				"IMAGO_DEFAULT_DBUSER" : "postgres",
				"IMAGO_DEFAULT_DBHOST" : "127.0.0.1",
				"IMAGO_DEFAULT_DBNAME" : "imago",
				"IMAGO_MASTER_DBHOST" : "127.0.0.1",
				"IMAGO_MASTER_DBNAME" : "master"
			},
			"externalConsole": false,
			"sourceMaps": false,
			"outDir": null
		}
	]
}
```

data.title: Weird cursor behavior
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.9.0 (1.9.0) - OS Version: macOS Sierra, 10.12.2 (16C67) After I upgrade VScode to the latest version (1.9.0), there is a weird cursor behavior while I am typing. The cursor always behind one character in the current line. If I move cursor backward one character, then it becomes what the second picture shows. Is it a feature or something else? It's weird.

data.title: Mac: file events are not reported when using workspace path with different casing (fixes #1426)
Limit codeLense animation to first appearance
data.body:
Now that we have references codelenses for TS in the January release I'd like to raise an issue with the pretty cool codelense animation. Currently it fades in every time it comes into view. This quickly gets distracting and hence annyoing when you navigate a lot in your files.

My request is therefor: either make the animation entirely configurable or show it only on first display of a codelense.

data.title: Misaligned cursor when editor.fontLigatures enabled
data.body:
Not a biggie, but it may at least help people running into the same issue;
TLDR; Quick fix is to disable ``` editor.fontLigatures```.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.3.0
- Extensions:
(confirmed not dependent on extensions)

Since one of the recent updates (2 days ago or so), when ``` editor.fontLigatures``` is enabled, and certain letter combinations are replaced by a ligature, the cursor will become out of sync, that is to say, the actual cursor is several characters behind. This affects only the selected line. Please see screenshots for clarification.

Notice where my cursor is (note: "fi" in "files" is replaced with a ligature, and takes up the space for one character)
![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1612079/22617070/e2b5ba46-eabb-11e6-888c-cc98eca740e2.png)

After I try to enter a dash to separate the words, it ends up here.
![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1612079/22617069/e2b27282-eabb-11e6-9eb8-126044cec615.png)

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. set ``` editor.fontLigatures``` to ```true```
2. make sure your ```editor.fontFamily``` has ```Menlo``` first, for example's sake.
3. Create a new (javascript) file, and enter ```let files = []; //this is a comment``` into it. You'll notice very clearly that as soon as the ligatures kick in, the cursor will be out of sync with the actual location.

Again, not a game-breaking bug, but it's a bug nonetheless.
Other than that, I'm very satisfied with vscode. Keep it up :)

data.title: Duplicated command on <tab> in the terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|vscode-css-modules|clinyong|0.1.2|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|docthis|joelday|0.3.10|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.1|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.22.0|
|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.2.5|
|ReactSnippets|xabikos|1.2.0|

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open terminal (using zsh in my case)
2. write `cd <tab>` or `cd sth<tab>` (where sth finds no match)
3. Notice the duplicate `cd` and the first cd cannot actually be removed, it's only visual.

_Note:_ this also occurs in non git directory

![kapture 2017-02-03 at 23 41 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1972567/22615799/d0899b04-ea6a-11e6-830c-eb0294b91fd1.gif)

data.title: Initial cursor location in terminal is wrong
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|vscode-css-modules|clinyong|0.1.2|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|docthis|joelday|0.3.10|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.1|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.22.0|
|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.2.5|
|ReactSnippets|xabikos|1.2.0|

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Setup custom terminal styles (with zsh for example)
2. Have characters on the right side of the current line (eg: git status)
3. Notice the issue

![kapture 2017-02-03 at 23 36 43](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1972567/22615742/a2039dee-ea69-11e6-87b2-f6effd54385f.gif)

The issue is not present when there's no character on the right side of the line.
![screen shot 2017-02-03 at 11 39 10 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1972567/22615769/fb9f5154-ea69-11e6-9bb4-796812162b97.jpg)
